Back then reddit was a pretty nice place. Those were the days of Ron Paul and the place was full of techies and libertarians. You could speak your mind in larger subreddits without being instantly banned. Free speech was still something that was universally valued.

The actual goals of SRS were entirely different. Let's say you and a small group of your friends wanted to take down reddit. How would you go about it? A direct attack would surely fail. But there are tactics that work against larger institutions, and that is using the weaknesses of that institution to make it attack itself from within. 

Their tactics included:

 - Coordination outside of reddit
 - Mass reporting of posts and subreddits
 - Coordinating with the media to publish hit pieces
 - Attacking fringe communities
 - False flag attacks: posting content that was illegal or against reddit rules to get subreddits banned
 - Kept lists of users and subreddits to target
 - Worked with reddit admins or had admin sympathizers

I'm sure there were other, more nefarious tactics used, but I haven't witnessed them personally.

They seem to derive pleasure from exercising their power and destroying what others have built. They are the kind of people who find pleasure in destroying another kid's sandcastle rather than building their own.

Other subreddits were created later, like AgainstHateSubreddits, which used similar tactics. 

Partly through their efforts reddit is what it is today.

That brings us to the cabal that has infested ruqqus. It's obvious they are they same people, if not physically, then in spirit. I've noticed a lot of people think I'm crazy and making up tinfoil hat insanity where everyone is conspiring against me.

Admittedly, I could do a better job of not coming across that way. Sometimes I state my suspicions as fact, and exaggerate them. This can end up as slanderous and to avoid that I wanted to clear some things up. So if I ended up making a false accusation about anyone, sorry about that.

No, I don't think there's a conspiracy. For example, yesterday I doubt @captainmeta4 actually woke up and said "how can I get @JosephGoebbels banned so @carpathianflorist can take his guilds?". But that is how I come across, especially during chaotic times like that. What I mean is, I feel like captainmeta4 did catch an incident but that he had a distaste for JG so it affected his decisions unknowingly. Similarly, DGK was banned for a really petty, likely accidental offense. Same thing there, I don't think captainmeta4 woke up and said "I want to get DGK banned" but I do think that the tension between them affected his decision and is why the punishment was so harsh; normally I'd expect him to have gotten a warning or a temp ban. Jason and Civil's stories are similar.

The discord mod thing, too, is the exact same way. Do the admins purposely pick out users they like and try to form an in-group? Do they try to think of all the ways they can give them extra special treatment? Of course not, but they do have a bias towards a few users for some reason and it ends up that way. They tend to pick the same people for most things, and just think that they can and should be trusted with more privileges than everyone else, ethics slipping their mind in this instance since they think it's not a big deal. When those users abuse their privileges or bend more minor rules, the admins see it differently than with anyone else; they're somewhat friends, and when someone you're friends with does something it looks more justified than it would otherwise. Likewise if someone you have a distrust for does something it seems worse than it otherwise would. I think that's what's happening here. I just think the admins are too carefree about these sorts of problems and incorrectly assert that they're not even happening, because from their perspective it seems normal. They need to be more careful about not showing favoritism or nepotism, and not giving any unnecessary extra privileges or reductions of privileges, or making biased decisions or giving preferential treatment; even if it's "not a big deal", a little leaven leavens the whole lump.

When I talk about a "cabal", I am *not* referring to any currently existing group on this site. Rather, I believe that this is the perfect setup for a cabal to develop in the future. I've seen it before; the site gets bigger, and the admins get more and more distant from the userbase because they have more work to do, while still maintaining contact with their clique. Eventually his develops into its own group completely cut off from the rest of the site, and that's when the cabal starts. That hasn't happened yet, but I think we're greatly underestimating how close we are to it. Also this cabal has nothing to do with RCP, it's mainly made up of users who are discord mods and maybe a few others like @carpathianflorist.

Admittedly, I could do a better job of not coming across that way. Sometimes I state my suspicions as fact, and exaggerate them. This can end up as slanderous and to avoid that I wanted to clear some things up. So if I ended up making a false accusation about anyone, sorry about that.

No, I don't think there's a conspiracy. For example, yesterday I doubt @captainmeta4 actually woke up and said "how can I get @JosephGoebbels banned so @carpathianflorist can take his guilds?". But that is how I come across, especially during chaotic times like that. What I mean is, I feel like captainmeta4 did catch an incident but that he had a distaste for JG so it affected his decisions unknowingly. Similarly, DGK was banned for a really petty, likely accidental offense. Same thing there, I don't think captainmeta4 woke up and said "I want to get DGK banned" but I do think that the tension between them affected his decision and is why the punishment was so harsh; normally I'd expect him to have gotten a warning or a temp ban. Jason and Civil's stories are similar.

The discord mod thing, too, is the exact same way. Do the admins purposely pick out users they like and try to form an in-group? Do they try to think of all the ways they can give them extra special treatment? Of course not, but they do have a bias towards a few users for some reason and it ends up that way. They tend to pick the same people for most things, and just think that they can and should be trusted with more privileges than everyone else, ethics slipping their mind in this instance since they think it's not a big deal. When those users abuse their privileges or bend more minor rules, the admins see it differently than with anyone else; they're somewhat friends, and when someone you're friends with does something it looks more justified than it would otherwise. Likewise if someone you have a distrust for does something it seems worse than it otherwise would. I think that's what's happening here. I just think the admins are too carefree about these sorts of problems and incorrectly assert that they're not even happening, because from their perspective it seems normal. They need to be more careful about not showing favoritism or nepotism, and not giving any unnecessary extra privileges or reductions of privileges, or making biased decisions or giving preferential treatment; even if it's "not a big deal", a little leaven leavens the whole lump.

When I talk about a "cabal", I am *not* referring to any currently existing group on this site. Rather, I believe that this is the perfect setup for a cabal to develop in the future. I've seen it before; the site gets bigger, and the admins get more and more distant from the userbase because they have more work to do, while still maintaining contact with their clique. Eventually his develops into its own group completely cut off from the rest of the site, and that's when the cabal starts. That hasn't happened yet, but I think we're greatly underestimating how close we are to it. Also this cabal has nothing to do with RCP, it's mainly made up of users who are discord mods and maybe a few others like @carpathianflorist.

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.
